file_metadata.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]
file_metadata.title: Automated shapeshifting for function recovery in damaged robots

chunks.text: A robot's mechanical parts can wear out or be damaged, especially in isolated or hostile environments where human repair is impossible.  Much research has focused on automating damage recovery in robots by adapting control strategies to the damaged structure. This paper presents a novel approach where the robot automatically recovers from damage by deforming its resting mechanical structure (shapeshifting) without altering its control policy.
chunks.chunk_summary: Robots can recover from damage by shapeshifting, changing their physical structure instead of just adapting their control strategies.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot demonstrated that shapeshifting, particularly after significant damage like losing all legs, can not only restore original locomotion but also improve speed. This suggests that shape change may be a more effective method for function recovery than control adaptation in certain situations.
chunks.chunk_summary: Shapeshifting can be more effective than control adaptation for recovering function after damage, sometimes even exceeding original performance.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Robots operating in remote, hazardous, or inaccessible environments require self-repair capabilities due to the difficulty of human intervention.  Previous research on robot damage recovery has focused on adapting control strategies to the damaged structure, assuming a fixed mechanical configuration.  This paper introduces a new approach: robots that deform their resting structure to recover function after damage.
chunks.chunk_summary: Robots in challenging environments need self-repair, and this paper explores structural deformation as a novel approach.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Advances in materials science and 3D printing allow for the creation of soft robots with numerous degrees of freedom, enabling structural deformation for regeneration or adaptation to damage.  Previous computational studies have shown structural change in discrete models like cellular automata, but not continuous geometric deformation in soft robots for functional recovery.
chunks.chunk_summary: Soft robots, with their ability to deform, offer a new avenue for damage recovery through structural change.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: This work builds upon previous research on robot damage recovery through controller adaptation.  Bongard et al. demonstrated how robots can internally model their geometry for action planning, while Cully et al. proposed pre-installing a behavioral repertoire for faster recovery.  However, these studies used robots with rigid components and limited degrees of freedom, focusing on control adaptation rather than structural deformation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Previous work focused on controller adaptation in robots with rigid structures and limited degrees of freedom.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: This paper presents a robot with many degrees of freedom and the ability to change the volume of its components, enabling structural deformation for damage recovery.  This approach allows for retaining a previously optimized controller while adapting the robot's shape to recover function.  The study demonstrates that shapeshifting can be advantageous, often outperforming controller adaptation alone in terms of recovered mobility.
chunks.chunk_summary: This paper investigates shapeshifting in a soft robot, showing its advantages over controller adaptation for damage recovery.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot is a quadruped made of 140 inflatable silicone "voxels."  A novel drip-molding technique was used to create thin, hollow silicone structures.  The robot's shape is controlled by selectively inflating these voxels.  Two versions of the robot were fabricated with different voxel wall thicknesses to explore the impact on attainable morphologies.
chunks.chunk_summary: The robot is a quadruped made of inflatable silicone voxels, with shape controlled by selective inflation.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot's voxels are inflated manually, but future implementations could use pressure regulators for continuous control.  The relationship between voxel wall thickness, internal pressure, and force is described by a spherical pressure vessel equation.  There's a trade-off between voxel weight and internal pressure: thicker walls increase weight but allow for higher operational pressure.
chunks.chunk_summary: Voxel inflation is currently manual, but future work will explore automated pressure control, considering the trade-off between wall thickness, pressure, and force.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot is simulated using Voxelyze, a voxel-based physics engine.  Voxels are simulated as particles connected by spring-like beams.  Material properties are specified at the particles and implemented as attributes of the beams.  A spherical envelope is used for collision detection, approximating the spherical expansion of the physical voxels.
chunks.chunk_summary: The robot's behavior is simulated using Voxelyze, a voxel-based physics engine that models voxels as particles connected by beams.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot's structure is defined by the placement of voxels, while its shape is determined by the resting volume of each voxel.  Damage removes voxels, and shape change is achieved by adjusting the resting volume of the remaining voxels.  The mechanical structure and resting shape are fixed during the evaluation period.
chunks.chunk_summary: Structure refers to voxel placement, shape to resting volume, and damage involves voxel removal and shape change.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The robot's controller reconfigures voxel volumes during evaluation.  Open-loop control with a central pattern generator is used, where each voxel's volume changes cyclically with a phase offset.  The controller is encoded as a Compositional Pattern-Producing Network (CPPN), mapping voxel indices to phase offsets.  This allows for complex behaviors like different gaits and propagating waves of excitation.
chunks.chunk_summary: The controller uses a CPPN to generate cyclical volume changes in voxels, enabling complex behaviors.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Nine damage scenarios are considered, involving amputation of varying numbers of legs and body sections.  Two recovery options are explored: controller readaptation, where a new controller is optimized for the damaged structure, and shapeshifting, where the shape of the damaged structure is optimized with the existing controller.
chunks.chunk_summary: Nine damage scenarios are tested, with two recovery options: controller readaptation and shapeshifting.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Shape change occurs before behavior, by adjusting the robot's resting shape.  The same CPPN used for controllers encodes the shape, outputting rest beam lengths.  Optimization searches for shape-encoding networks that, when combined with the original controller, recover forward movement.
chunks.chunk_summary: Shape change is optimized before behavior using a CPPN to encode resting beam lengths for improved locomotion.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Age-Fitness-Pareto Optimization is used to optimize shapes and control policies for displacement.  The algorithm uses Pareto dominance and an "age" objective to promote diversity and prevent premature convergence.  Mutations modify the encoding network's architecture and weights.
chunks.chunk_summary: Age-Fitness-Pareto Optimization is used to optimize shapes and controllers, promoting diversity and preventing premature convergence.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Twenty controllers were optimized for forward movement in the undamaged simulated quadruped.  The robot was then subjected to nine damage scenarios, and two recovery options (controller readaptation and shapeshifting) were tested for each scenario and controller.  This resulted in 360 independent trials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Twenty controllers were optimized, and then 360 trials tested two recovery options across nine damage scenarios.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Shape change generally outperformed controller readaptation in terms of recovered performance.  In some cases, the recovered performance exceeded the original, undamaged performance.  This was not solely due to increased volume, as an isometrically enlarged robot did not show increased speed.  The efficacy of shapeshifting stems from how the remaining structure's shape is deformed, affecting posture, mass distribution, and energy storage during locomotion.
chunks.chunk_summary: Shapeshifting outperformed controller readaptation, with recovered performance sometimes exceeding the original, and this wasn't solely due to increased volume.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Shapeshifting led to diverse recovery strategies, while controller readaptation often converged on crawling.  Shapeshifting frequently involved regenerating missing legs, especially when all four legs were amputated.  Other strategies included contracting undamaged legs, expanding the spine, and splaying the pelvis.  The specific strategy depended on the type and extent of damage.
chunks.chunk_summary: Shapeshifting resulted in diverse recovery strategies, including leg regeneration, while controller readaptation often converged on crawling.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Attempts were made to transfer simulated shape changes to a physical robot.  The robot could expand the top layer of voxels but struggled to achieve the complex shapes seen in simulation.  Limitations included inconsistent voxel expansion and friction between the robot and the surface.  Future work will incorporate strain sensors and closed-loop control for more precise shape control.
chunks.chunk_summary: Transferring simulated shapes to a physical robot showed promise but faced challenges with inconsistent voxel expansion and friction.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: This paper introduces a novel approach to robot damage recovery through shapeshifting, demonstrating its effectiveness compared to controller adaptation.  Future work will focus on improving the sim-to-real transfer of morphing machines and combining control and shape readaptation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Shapeshifting is a promising approach to robot damage recovery, and future work will refine sim-to-real transfer and combine it with control adaptation.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Animals often recover from limb loss through morphological changes rather than just control adaptation.  Examples include the two-legged goat that adopted an upright posture and animals that regenerate lost limbs or organs.  These biological examples highlight the importance of structural deformation in damage recovery.
chunks.chunk_summary: Animals demonstrate the importance of morphological change, not just control adaptation, for recovering from limb loss.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: Biological regeneration involves several mechanisms relevant to robotics: directing low-level components towards large-scale goals, robustness under novel conditions, computational control in a changing medium, and memory retention after regeneration.  Implementing these capabilities in artificial systems could advance both robotics and biological understanding.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological regeneration mechanisms, such as goal-directed low-level control and robustness, offer insights for robotics.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]

chunks.text: The ability of robots to regenerate limbs depends on the materials used.  Soft robots, with their ability to change structural and material properties, offer greater potential for shapeshifting than rigid robots.  This research could lead to new robotic systems and provide insights into biological processes like developmental plasticity and regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Soft robots, capable of changing structural and material properties, hold greater promise for shapeshifting and can inform biological research.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Stephanie Walker", "Dylan Shah", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio", "Josh Bongard"]
